## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 413, 768, 533]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.

## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[74, 98, 595, 532]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1\mathrm{u} = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81\mathrm{m s}^{- 2}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[416, 100, 534, 136]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[416, 153, 507, 170]]<|/det|>
\[W = p\Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[423, 183, 512, 214]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{Gm}{r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[423, 223, 500, 240]]<|/det|>
\[p = \rho gh\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[423, 250, 534, 280]]<|/det|>
\[p = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V} (c^2)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[423, 289, 512, 306]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\omega^2 x\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[423, 322, 580, 358]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_{0}\cos \omega t\] \[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{(\chi_{0}^{2} - x^{2})}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[423, 361, 512, 395]]<|/det|>
\[f_{0} = \frac{f_{s}V}{\nu\pm\nu_{s}}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[423, 405, 512, 438]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[411, 445, 598, 463]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_{1} + 1 / C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[423, 475, 567, 494]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_{1} + C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[416, 504, 500, 530]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[423, 540, 504, 559]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[416, 572, 567, 591]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[411, 604, 598, 623]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_{1} + 1 / R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[416, 635, 488, 667]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{H}} = \frac{BI}{ntq}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[423, 680, 534, 697]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[423, 711, 552, 730]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[423, 739, 512, 772]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[281, 68, 667, 85]]<|/det|> Answer **all** the questions in the spaces provided. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 97, 94, 115]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 97, 141, 115]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 97, 270, 115]]<|/det|> Define density. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 156, 878, 173]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 185, 141, 203]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 185, 546, 203]]<|/det|> Fig. 1.1 shows a solid pyramid with a square base. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[292, 210, 648, 361]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 375, 507, 393]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 405, 455, 424]]<|/det|> The mass \(m\) of the pyramid is given by <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 428, 522, 456]]<|/det|> \[m = \frac{1}{3}\rho hx^{2}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 464, 556, 483]]<|/det|> where \(\rho\) is the density of the material of the pyramid, <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 479, 353, 497]]<|/det|> \(h\) is the height, and <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 494, 510, 512]]<|/det|> \(x\) is the length of each side of the base. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 523, 526, 541]]<|/det|> Measurements are taken as shown in Table 1.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 552, 515, 570]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[227, 581, 724, 693]]<|/det|>
quantitymeasurementpercentage uncertainty
\(m\)19.5 g\(\pm 2\%\)
\(x\)4.0 cm\(\pm 5\%\)
\(h\)4.8 cm\(\pm 4\%\)
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 705, 171, 724]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 705, 544, 724]]<|/det|> Calculate the absolute uncertainty in length \(x\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[378, 838, 876, 856]]<|/det|>
absolute uncertainty = .................................................. $cm$ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[868, 838, 878, 856]]<|/det|> [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 68, 173, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 67, 687, 85]]<|/det|>
The density \(\rho\) is calculated from the measurements in Table 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 97, 702, 114]]<|/det|>
Determine the percentage uncertainty in the calculated value of \(\rho\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[358, 288, 876, 306]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty = .................................................... % [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 319, 139, 337]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 319, 781, 337]]<|/det|>
The square base of the pyramid in **(b)** rests on the horizontal surface of a bench.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 348, 876, 380]]<|/det|>
Use data from Table 1.1 to calculate the average pressure of the pyramid on the surface of the bench. The uncertainty in your answer is not required.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[467, 567, 876, 586]]<|/det|>
<form>pressure = .................................................... $Pa$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[803, 597, 876, 615]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 68, 91, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 67, 875, 102]]<|/det|>
A person uses a trolley to move suitcases at an airport. The total mass of the trolley and suitcases is \(72\mathrm{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 112, 138, 129]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 112, 875, 174]]<|/det|>
The person pushes the trolley and suitcases along a horizontal surface with a constant speed of \(1.4 \text{m s}^{-1}\) and then releases the trolley. The released trolley moves in a straight line and comes to rest. Assume that a constant total resistive force of \(18 \text{N}\) opposes the motion of the trolley and suitcases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 186, 175, 203]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 186, 875, 217]]<|/det|>
Calculate the power required to overcome the total resistive force on the trolley and suitcases when they move with a constant speed of \(1.4 \text{m s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[490, 317, 875, 336]]<|/det|>
<form>power = .................................................... W [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 348, 173, 365]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 348, 755, 365]]<|/det|>
Calculate the time taken for the trolley to come to rest after it is released.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[502, 543, 876, 560]]<|/det|>
<form>time = .................................................... s [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 573, 141, 591]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 573, 871, 591]]<|/det|>
At another place in the airport, the trolley and suitcases are on a slope, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[170, 599, 774, 740]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[388, 758, 562, 777]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 789, 875, 821]]<|/det|>
The person releases the trolley from rest at point X. The trolley moves down the slope in a straight line towards point Y. The distance along the slope between points X and Y is \(9.5 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 834, 875, 880]]<|/det|>
The component \(F\) of the weight of the trolley and suitcases that acts along the slope is \(54 \text{N}\). Assume that a constant total resistive force of \(18 \text{N}\) opposes the motion of the trolley and suitcases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 68, 175, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 67, 527, 85]]<|/det|>
Calculate the speed of the trolley at point Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[489, 259, 876, 277]]<|/det|>
<form>speed = ................................................. m s\(^{-1}\) [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 288, 173, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 288, 756, 306]]<|/det|>
Calculate the work done by \(F\) for the movement of the trolley from X to Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 377, 876, 395]]<|/det|>
<form>work done = .................................................... J [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[136, 406, 173, 425]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 406, 544, 425]]<|/det|>
The trolley is released at point X at time \(t = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 437, 875, 469]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 2.2, sketch a graph to show the variation with time \(t\) of the work done by \(F\) for the movement of the trolley from X to Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 466, 638, 484]]<|/det|>
Numerical values of the work done and \(t\) are not required.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[339, 491, 606, 648]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 664, 509, 682]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 680, 878, 698]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 708, 139, 727]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 708, 875, 742]]<|/det|>
The angle of the slope in **(b)** is constant. The frictional forces acting on the wheels of the moving trolley are also constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 753, 875, 785]]<|/det|>
Explain why, in practice, it is incorrect to assume that the total resistive force opposing the motion of the trolley and suitcases is constant as the trolley moves between X and Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[791, 848, 876, 866]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[791, 855, 876, 874]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 12]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 68, 89, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 67, 875, 101]]<|/det|>
A pendulum consists of a solid sphere suspended by a string from a fixed point P, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 108, 685, 339]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[388, 355, 562, 373]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 384, 875, 448]]<|/det|>
The sphere swings from side to side. At one instant the sphere is at its lowest position X, where it has kinetic energy \(0.86 \text{J}\) and momentum \(0.72 \text{N s}\) in a horizontal direction. A short time later the sphere is at position Y, where it is momentarily stationary at a maximum vertical height \(h\) above position X.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 458, 761, 477]]<|/det|>
The string has a fixed length and negligible weight. Air resistance is also negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 488, 139, 507]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 488, 875, 520]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 3.1, draw a solid line to represent the displacement of the centre of the sphere at position Y from position X.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 504, 876, 521]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 532, 139, 550]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 532, 499, 550]]<|/det|>
Show that the mass of the sphere is \(0.30 \text{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 797, 876, 816]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 67, 139, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 67, 299, 85]]<|/det|>
Calculate height \(h\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[526, 198, 876, 217]]<|/det|>
<form>h = .................................................... m [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 230, 139, 248]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 228, 876, 262]]<|/det|>
The distance between point P and the centre of the sphere is \(0.93 \text{m}\). When the sphere is at position Y, the string is at an angle \(\theta\) to the vertical.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 273, 299, 291]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\theta\) is \(47^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 392, 876, 410]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 421, 139, 440]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 420, 752, 440]]<|/det|>
For the sphere at position Y, calculate the moment of its weight about point P.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[472, 583, 876, 601]]<|/det|>
<form>moment = ................................................. Nm [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 612, 136, 631]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 612, 836, 631]]<|/det|>
State and explain whether the sphere is in equilibrium when it is stationary at position Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[791, 693, 876, 710]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[792, 700, 876, 718]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 10]

<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 67, 141, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 67, 620, 85]]<|/det|>
For a progressive wave, state what is meant by wavelength.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 125, 876, 144]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 156, 141, 175]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 155, 672, 174]]<|/det|>
A light wave from a laser has a wavelength of \(460\mathrm{nm}\) in a vacuum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 186, 410, 203]]<|/det|>
Calculate the period of the wave.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[487, 380, 876, 397]]<|/det|>
<form>period = .................................................... $s$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[870, 381, 878, 400]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 411, 139, 428]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 410, 672, 428]]<|/det|>
The light from the laser is incident normally on a diffraction grating.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 439, 586, 457]]<|/det|>
Describe the diffraction of the light waves at the grating.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 528, 876, 546]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 558, 141, 575]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 556, 875, 604]]<|/det|>
A diffraction grating is used with different wavelengths of visible light. The angle \(\theta\) of the **fourth**-order maximum from the zero-order (central) maximum is measured for each wavelength. The variation with wavelength \(\lambda\) of \(\sin \theta\) is shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 612, 672, 797]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 814, 507, 833]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 67, 175, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 67, 428, 85]]<|/det|>
The gradient of the graph is \(G\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 97, 875, 129]]<|/det|>
Determine an expression, in terms of \(G\), for the distance \(d\) between the centres of two adjacent slits in the diffraction grating.
